sen.j: 丁銀（ちょうぎん）とは、日本国内において主に商取引用として室町時代後期から明治維新まで流通した銀貨である。
sen.e: Chogin is the name of the silver coins which were in circulation, mainly for business transaction, from the late Muromachi period to the Meiji Restoration in Japan.
Chogin is the name of the silver coins which were in circulation, mainly for business transaction, from the late Muromachi period to the Meiji Restoration in Japan.
Chogin is the name of the silver coins which were in circulation, mainly for business transaction, from the late Muromachi period to the Meiji Restoration in Japan.

sen.j: 丁銀という名称は『金銀図録』の記述によれば棒状の銀塊の意味である鋌銀（ちょうぎん）が挺銀（ちょうぎん）を経て変化したものとされる。
sen.e: According to "Kinginzuroku" (Gold & Silver catalog), originally 鋌銀 meant silver bars, then it changed to 挺銀, then to 丁銀, although the words are all pronounced as Chogin.
sen.cmt: 『金銀図録』の書名が抜けていましたので追加しました。
sen.e: According to "Kinginzuroku" (Gold & Silver catalog), originally Chogin written as 鋌銀 meant silver bars, later the character was changed to 挺銀, then to 丁銀, although all were pronounced as Chogin.
sen.cmt: 原文に沿って修正しました。
sen.e: According to "Kinginzuroku" (Gold & Silver catalog), originally Chogin written as 鋌銀 meant silver bars, later the character was changed to 挺銀, then to 丁銀, although all were pronounced as Chogin.

sen.j: 形状は、ナマコ形と呼ばれるやや不揃いな棒状の銀塊で、量目（質量）は不定だがおおよそ43匁（約161.25グラム）前後。
sen.e: Chogin are various seacucumber-shaped silver ingots; although their rime (weighed value or mass) are not the same, they were approximately 161.25g.
Chogin were various seacucumber-shaped silver ingots; although their rime (weighed value or mass) were not the same, they were approximately 161.25g.
Chogin were various seacucumber-shaped silver ingots; although their rime (weighed value or mass) were not the same, they were approximately 161.25g.

sen.j: 額面は記載されておらず、量目によって貨幣価値が決まる秤量銀貨である。
sen.e: They did not have any face value but they were a silver-by-weight standard in which the value is decided by the weight.
They did not have any face value but they were a silver-by-weight standard in which the value was decided by the weight.
They did not have any face value but they were a silver-by-weight standard in which the value was decided by the weight.

sen.j: 額面は天秤による量目の実測値で、商取引において銀何貫、銀何匁と表記される銀目取引の通貨単位であった。
sen.e: The value was determined by working out its ryome of actual weight value with a balanced scale and Chogin was the currency unit of silver grain trade referred to as "Silver 〇 kan (1 kan=3.75Kg)" or "Silver 〇 monme (1 monme=3.75g)".
sen.cmt: 「銀目」で調べると "silver grain'と出て来るのですが、 'grain'は必要でしょうか。
sen.e: The value was determined by the actual measurement in ryome (a weighted value) using a balanced scale and Chogin was the currency unit of Ginme (silver grain) trade referred to as "Silver 〇 kan (1 kan=3.75Kg)" or "Silver 〇 monme (1 monme=3.75g)".
sen.cmt: 原文に沿って修正しました。
sen.e: Chogin, whose value was determined by its actual weight in ryome (a weighted value) using a balanced scale, was the currency unit for Ginme (silver grain) trade, and it was referred to as "Silver X kan" (1 kan=3.75 kg) or "Silver X monme" (1 monme=3.75 g).

sen.j: また賞賜目的には43匁を銀一枚とする単位が用いられた。
sen.e: For a prize or award, the unit of one silver sheet=43 monme was used.
For a prize or award, the unit of one silver sheet=43 monme was used.
For a prize or award, the unit of one silver sheet=43 monme was used.

sen.j: なお、当時用いられた分銅の質量単位は「両」であったが、小判の通貨単位との混同を避けるため「両」は用いられなかった。
sen.e: At that time, the mass unit for the fundo (counterweight) was called 'ryo' but it was also the unit for oval gold coins so, to avoid any confusion, the 'ryo' unit was not used in weighing Chogin.
At that time, the mass unit for the fundo (counterweight) was called 'ryo' but it was also the unit for oval gold coins so, to avoid any confusion, the 'ryo' unit was not used in weighing Chogin.
At that time, the mass unit for the fundo (counterweight) was called 'ryo' but it was also the unit for oval gold coins so, to avoid any confusion, the 'ryo' unit was not used in weighing Chogin.

sen.j: 一方中華人民共和国では、当時秤量銀貨（銀錠）の額面単位に「両」を用いていた。
sen.e: In the People's Republic of China at that time, they were using the 'ryo' unit to show the face value of silver-by-weight standard coins.
In the People's Republic of China at that time, the 'ryo' unit was used to show the face value of silver-by-weight standard coins.
sen.cmt: they were using the 'ryo' unit → the 'ryo' unit was used
sen.e: In the People's Republic of China at that time, the 'ryo' unit was used to show the face value of silver-by-weight standard coins.

sen.j: 江戸時代以前には、灰吹銀および極印銀が、鋳造者である富商や両替商の極印によって流通した。
sen.e: Before the Edo period, refined silver coins and hallmarked silver coins were circulated with the hallmarks of wealthy coiners and money-exchange businessmen.
sen.cmt: "cupellate"という単語の意味が分かるネイティブはほとんどいないようですので、同義語を探しましたが、これも見つかりませんでした。でも、http://www.wordnik.com/words/cupellationに"A refining process …"とあることから、"refine"に相当すると考え、これを使用しました。
sen.e: Before the Edo period, refined silver coins and hallmarked silver coins were circulated with the hallmarks of wealthy coiners and money-exchange businessmen.
Before the Edo period, refined silver coins and hallmarked silver coins were circulated with the hallmarks of wealthy coiners and money-exchange businessmen.

sen.j: また、当時は切り遣いの慣行が見られた。
sen.e: There was also a custom of cutting them into smaller pieces and using them as another unit.
There was also a custom of cutting them into small pieces and using them as another unit.
There was also a custom of cutting them into small pieces and using them as another unit.

sen.j: これらが「地方銀」と呼ばれる領国貨幣である。
sen.e: These are called 'Chihogin', the territorial currency of a Daimyo.
These were called 'Chihogin', the territorial currency of Daimyo.
These were called 'Chihogin', the territorial currency of Daimyo.

sen.j: やがて、灰吹銀を譲葉のような形状に叩き伸ばして極印を打った銀貨が登場した。
sen.e: At that time, they introduced silver coins were made from beaten, refined silver to a leafy shape and with hallmarks.
At that time, a silver coin with hallmark appeared, which was made by beating and refining cupellated silver to a leafy shape..
sen.cmt: 原文に沿って修正しました。
sen.e: At that time, a silver coin with a hallmark was introduced, and this was made by beating silver that had been refined by cupellation into a leaf shape.

sen.j: 16世紀中頃から銀山の開発および灰吹法の普及により国内の銀の産出が急増し始めた。
sen.e: From the mid sixth century, the silver production in Japan increased rapidly because of silver mine development and the promotion of the refining skills.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: From the mid sixth century, the silver production in Japan increased rapidly because of silver mine development and the development of cupellation-refining skills.
sen.cmt: the promotion of the refining skills. → the development of cupellation-refining skills.
sen.e: From the mid sixth century, the silver production in Japan increased rapidly because of silver mine development and the development of cupellation-refining skills.

sen.j: 銀屋（ぎんや/かなや/かねや）あるいは銀吹屋（ぎんふきや）と呼ばれた銀地金の売買および精錬などを手掛ける者が現れ、後の銀座 (歴史)および両替商の前身となった。
sen.e: Ginya (also known as Kanaya, or Kaneya) who dealt with the silver ingot trade and Ginfukiya, silver refiners, appeared and became the predecessor of the later Ginza (silver mint) and money-exchange businesses.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。「銀座 (歴史)」の（歴史）は現在の地名としての「銀座」と区別するためにタイトルに付けられたもののようです。原文にはないので訳文では省いてあります。
sen.e: Ginya (also known as Kanaya, or Kaneya) who dealt with the silver ingot trade and Ginfukiya, silver refiners, appeared and became the predecessor of the later Ginza (silver mint) and money-exchange businesses.

Ginya (also known as Kanaya, or Kaneya) who dealt with the silver ingot trade and Ginfukiya, silver refiners, appeared and became the predecessor of the later Ginza (silver mint) and money-exchange businesses.

sen.j: 堺市の南鐐座の銀細工師湯浅作兵衛らは諸国の灰吹銀を集め極印を打って売買していたが、銀座 (歴史)伏見・銀座町設立前に徳川家康の上覧に供するための丁銀を試鋳した。
sen.e: In Nanryoza, Sakai City, the silver craftsman Sakube YUASA had been collecting refined silver coins and selling them again after engraving hallmarks, but with other craftsmen, he was asked to make samples to show Ieyasu TOKUGAWA before the shogun opened the Ginza in Fushimi town.

In Nanryoza, Sakai City, the silver craftsman Sakube YUASA had been collecting refined silver coins and selling them again after engraving hallmarks, but with other craftsmen, he was asked to make samples to show Ieyasu TOKUGAWA before the shogun opened the Ginza in Fushimi town.

In Nanryoza, Sakai City, the silver craftsman Sakube YUASA had been collecting refined silver coins and selling them again after engraving hallmarks, but with other craftsmen, he was asked to make samples to show Ieyasu TOKUGAWA before the shogun opened the Ginza in Fushimi town.

sen.j: この時代のものは古丁銀（こちょうぎん）とよばれる。
sen.e: The Chogin at that time were called Kochogin (old Chogin).
The Chogin at that time were called Kochogin (old Chogin).
The Chogin at that time were called Kochogin (old Chogin).

sen.j: またこれらを切り遣いしたものは切銀（きりぎん）と呼ばれる。
sen.e: The coins made from cut pieces of Kochogin were called Kirigin (cut silver coins).
The coins made from cut pieces of Kochogin were called Kirigin (cut silver coins).
The coins made from cut pieces of Kochogin were called Kirigin (cut silver coins).

sen.j: 極印銀および古丁銀の銀品位は各地の銀山により不定であったが、おおむね90%以上であった。
sen.e: The purity of the refined silver coins and Kochogin were mostly higher than 90%, although it varied depending on which mines produced the silver.
The purity of the refined silver coins and Kochogin were mostly higher than 90%, although it varied depending on which mines produced the silver.
The purity of the refined silver coins and Kochogin were mostly higher than 90%, although it varied depending on which mines produced the silver.

sen.j: 中でも石見銀山産出の銀で作られた、石州銀（ソーマ銀）（佐摩）は良質で量的にも潤沢であったが、銀産地による品位のバラつきは取引上甚だ不便なものであった。
sen.e: Coins of the Sekishu silver mine (Soma Silver) (from Samamura) and from the Iwami silver mine were high quality and abundant; but quality was inconsistent as it varied between the mines.

Among them, Sekishu silver coin (Soma Silver) (from Sama), which was made of silver produced in Iwami silver mine, was in high quality and abundant; however, the quality in general was inconsistent according to mines, causing quite inconvenience in trade.

Among them, Sekishu silver coin (Soma Silver) (from Sama), which was made of silver produced in Iwami silver mine, was in high quality and abundant; however, the quality in general was inconsistent according to mines, causing quite inconvenience in trade.

sen.j: 慶長6年（1601年）には、伏見銀座から慶長丁銀が鋳造され、以後、江戸幕府によって品位を一定に定められた丁銀が発行され、元和 (日本)年間以降は常に小額通貨である同品位の豆板銀（小玉銀）を伴って発行された。
sen.e: In 1601, Keicho Chogin (oval silver coins) were made in Fushimi Ginza (silver mint) and since then, Chogin of a consistent standard had been coined by the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) and after the Genwa era, the same quality Mameitagin (small coins) were made as a permanent small currency unit.

In 1601, Keicho Chogin (oval silver coins) were made in Fushimi Ginza (silver mint) and since then, Chogin of a consistent standard had been coined by the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) and after the Genwa era, Mameitagin (small coins) of the same quality were made as a permanent small currency unit.
sen.cmt: the same quality Mameitagin (small coins) were → Mameitagin (small coins) of the same quality were
sen.e: In 1601, Keicho Chogin (oval silver coins) were made in Fushimi Ginza (silver mint) and since then, Chogin of a consistent standard had been coined by the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) and after the Genwa era, Mameitagin (small coins) of the same quality were made as a permanent small currency unit.

sen.j: 銀座では常に鋳造された丁銀は灰吹法による糺吹（ただしふき）すなわち銀品位の抜き取り検査が行われ、規定の品位の基準を満たさないものは吹き戻され作り直された。
sen.e: In Ginza, Chogin were constantly checked with Tadashifuki whereby silver was taken out of the coins and if they were not up to the quality standard, they had to be refined again.

In Ginza, Chogin had constantly a surprise checked with Tadashifuki, cupellated method to see the percentage of constituent of silver, and those which were not up to the quality standard were refined again.
sen.cmt: 原文に沿って修正しました。
sen.e: Sampling checks were constantly conducted on Chogin to ascertain the percentage of silver in them by applying the process of cupellation after lead had been added to remove any impurities; those which did not meet the required quality standard were refined again.
sen.cmt: 「抜き取り検査」にsuprsiseは関係ないので、sampling checksとしました。「灰吹法」cupellation＝「鉱石や製錬過程で生じる副産物から金銀を回収するのに使われた。炉の下面にくぼみをこしらえて灰を詰め、その上にのせた金銀と鉛の混合物を加熱すると、鉛は熔け出して灰に吸収され、後に金銀の塊だけが残る。」糺吹（ただしふき）＝「鋳造された丁銀の銀品位が正しいか否かを検査するため、常是手代立会いの下、鉛を加えて吹き戻され灰吹法により含有銀量が改められた。これを糺吹（ただしふき）と呼ぶ。」

sen.j: 江戸時代には、主に大坂を中心とした西日本および北陸、東北と広域に亘って流通した。
sen.e: In the Edo period, Chogin were circulated widely in western Japan mainly in the Osaka and Hokuriku and Tohoku regions.
In the Edo period, Chogin were circulated widely in western Japan mainly in the Osaka and Hokuriku and Tohoku regions.
In the Edo period, Chogin were circulated widely in western Japan mainly in the Osaka and Hokuriku and Tohoku regions.

sen.j: 丁銀は額面の記載されていない秤量貨幣で、本来は使用のごとに量目を量る必要があるが、それでは扱いづらいため、包銀の形で用いられた。
sen.e: Because Chogin did not have a face value and was Hyodo kahei (currency valued by weight) and their Ryome needed to be weighed every time they were used, they were inconvenient, so they were used in the form of Hogin.

Because Chogin did not have a face value and was Hyodo kahei (currency valued by weight) and their Ryome needed to be weighed every time they were used, they were inconvenient, so they were used in the form of Hogin.

Because Chogin did not have a face value and was Hyodo kahei (currency valued by weight) and their Ryome needed to be weighed every time they were used, they were inconvenient, so they were used in the form of Hogin.

sen.j: これは、丁銀と同品位の少額貨幣である豆板銀を合わせて一定の量目（恩賞および献上用には銀一枚43匁、商取引用には五百目など）にし、紙に包んで封印したものである。
sen.e: A Hogin is a sealed bag with enough Chogin and same-quality Mameitagin to make it in a certain ryome (one silver sheet of 43 monme for a prize or present, 500 ryome for business transactions).

This was wrapped silver that Chogin and same-quality Mameitagin in a certain ryome (for example, one silver sheet of 43 monme for a prize or present, 500 ryome for business transactions) were wrapped together in paper and sealed.
sen.cmt: 原文に沿って修正しました。
sen.e: A Hogin was a sealed paper bag that contained both Chogin and Mameitagin of the same quality that had been combined to attain a certain ryome (e.g. one silver sheet of 43 monme for a prize or present and 500 ryome for business transactions).
sen.cmt: 基本的に翻訳者の訳に戻して、少し変更しました。

sen.j: 銀数十匁にもなる丁銀は日常生活には高額過ぎ、豆板銀と異なり包封していない裸銀として支払いに用いられることはほとんど無かった。
sen.e: Chogin of several scores of monme were too high in value to be used in everyday life, so unlike Mameitagin, they were hardly used on their own for payment.

Chogin, which was equivalent as high as several ten scores of monme, were too high in value to be used in everyday life, so unlike Mameitagin, unwrapped Chogin were hardly used on their own for payment.
sen.cmt: 原文に沿って修正しました。
sen.e: Chogin, which had a value that was several dozens of times higher than that of monme, were too high in value to be used in everyday life, so unlike Mameitagin, they were hardly ever used as they were for payment unless they were sealed in the form of Hogin.

sen.j: 秤量銀貨の量目を定め、包封することは両替商の重要な仕事のひとつである。
sen.e: Deciding the ryome of silver-by-weight coins and packing them in bags was one of the important jobs for money-exchangers.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Deciding the ryome of silver-by-weight coins and packing them in bags was one of the important jobs for money-exchangers.
Deciding the ryome of silver-by-weight coins and packing them in bags was one of the important jobs for money-exchangers.

sen.j: 諸藩における年貢米の売り上げ、物品購入代金の管理を任命された両替商、および天領である石見銀山、生野銀山などで産出される上納灰吹銀の量目を掛け改めた役職は掛屋（かけや）とも呼ばれた。
sen.e: Both money exchangers, who were appointed to calculate per Domain sale of rice collected as annual tax and money management for the purchases of goods, and people in the position for reapplying ryome of refined silver produced in Iwami Ginzan and Ikuno Ginzan Silver Mines, tenryo (a shogunal demesne) and paid to the authorities, were also called Kakeya.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。文章が長過ぎるのですが適当に区切ることができませんでした。
sen.e: Money exchangers, who were appointed to calculate the sales of annual rice tax per Domain and to manage money for the purchases of goods, and people in charge of reapplying the ryome of cupellated silver which was produced in Iwami Ginzan and Ikuno Ginzan Silver Mines, tenryo (a shogunal demesne), and paid to the authorities, were also called Kakeya.
sen.cmt: 原文に沿って修正しました。
sen.e: The name given to money exchangers who were appointed to calculate the revenue from each domain's annual rice tax and to manage money for the purchasing of goods was "Kakeya"; this name was also used for persons in charge of reapplying the ryome for cupellated silver that had been produced in the Iwami Ginzan and Ikuno Ginzan Silver Mines (which were located in lands owned by the bakufu) and paid to the authorities.
sen.cmt: 全体的に書き換えました。

sen.j: 慶応4年（1868年）5月に、明治維新政府は銀目廃止の布令を出し、丁銀は流通停止となった。
sen.e: In May 1868, the Meiji Restoration government officially announced the abolition of silver grain and Chogin circulation ceased.
sen.cmt: 「銀目」で調べると "silver grain'と出て来るのですが、 'grain'は必要でしょうか。
sen.e: In May 1868, the Meiji Restoration government officially announced the abolition of Ginme (silver grain) and Chogin circulation ceased.
sen.cmt: 銀目という制度の廃止なので、そのように修正しました。
sen.e: In May 1868, the Meiji Restoration government officially announced the abolition of Ginme (silver grain) and Chogin circulation ceased.

sen.j: 古丁銀は以下のものが知られているが、いずれも現存極めて稀少である。
sen.e: Well-known Kochogin are as follows, but they are all very rare:
Well-known Kochogin are as follows, but they all rarely remain:
sen.cmt: but they all rarely remain:にしました。
sen.e: Well-known Kochogin are as follows, but they are now all very rare:
sen.cmt: 翻訳者の訳に戻しました。

sen.j: 萩古丁銀（はぎこちょうぎん）：無銘の丁銀で石州丁銀（せきしゅうちょうぎん）ともいい、出土地にちなみ萩市と称される。
sen.e: Hagiko Chogin: Chogin without a hallmark, also called as Sekishu Chogin, are thought to be made in Hagi City.
Hagiko Chogin: Chogin without a hallmark, also called as Sekishu Chogin, are thought to be made in Hagi City.
Hagiko Chogin: Chogin without a hallmark, also called as Sekishu Chogin, are thought to be made in Hagi City.

sen.j: 譲葉丁銀（ゆずりはちょうぎん）：萩古丁銀より細長い譲葉の様な形状のもの。
sen.e: Yuzuriha Chogin: These are Chogin in a longer Yuzuriha leaf shape than Hagiko Chogin.
Yuzuriha Chogin: These are Chogin in a longer Yuzuriha leaf shape than Hagiko Chogin.
Yuzuriha Chogin: These are Chogin in a longer Yuzuriha leaf shape than Hagiko Chogin.

sen.j: 御取納丁銀（おとりおさめちょうぎん）：譲葉丁銀に「御取納」の極印が打たれ、毛利氏が永禄3年（1560年）、正親町天皇の即位礼のとき献上したもの。
sen.e: Otoriosame Chogin: Yuzuriha Chogin with '御取納' (Otoriosame) hallmarked and were presented by the Mori clan at the Emperor Ogimachi's enthronement ceremony in 1560.
Otoriosame Chogin: Yuzuriha Chogin with '御取納' (Otoriosame) hallmarked and were presented by the Mori clan at the Emperor Ogimachi's enthronement ceremony in 1560.
Otoriosame Chogin: Yuzuriha Chogin with '御取納' (Otoriosame) hallmarked and were presented by the Mori clan at the Emperor Ogimachi's enthronement ceremony in 1560.

sen.j: 文禄石州丁銀（ぶんろくせきしゅうちょうぎん）：文禄2年（1593年）、文禄の役で豊臣秀吉が諸大名への賞賜用として鋳造させたもの。
sen.e: Bunrokusekishu Chogin: These Chogin were ordered by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI in 1593 as a present for each territorial Daimyo at the Bunroku War.
Bunrokusekishu Chogin: These Chogin were ordered by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI in 1593 as a present for each territorial Daimyo at the Bunroku War.
Bunrokusekishu Chogin: These Chogin were ordered by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI in 1593 as a present for each territorial Daimyo at the Bunroku War.

sen.j: 御公用丁銀（ごくようちょうぎん）：「御公用」の極印が打たれ、毛利氏が朝廷に貢納したもの。
sen.e: Gokuyo Chogin: Chogin with '御公用' (Gokuyo) hallmarked and were presented by the Mori clan to the Chotei (Imperial Court).
Gokuyo Chogin: Chogin with '御公用' (Gokuyo) hallmarked and were presented by the Mori clan to the Chotei (Imperial Court).
Gokuyo Chogin: Chogin with '御公用' (Gokuyo) hallmarked and were presented by the Mori clan to the Chotei (Imperial Court).

sen.j: 博多御公用丁銀（はかたごくようちょうぎん）：「御公用」「文禄二中山与左衛門」の極印が打たれ、文禄の役の際、豊臣秀吉が鋳造させたとされる。
sen.e: Hakatagokuyo Chogin: Chogin with '御公用' (Gokuyo) and '文禄二中山与左衛門' (Second year of the Buroku era, Yozaemon NAKAYAMA) hallmarked and were said to be ordered by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI at the Bunroku War.
Hakatagokuyo Chogin: Chogin with '御公用' (Gokuyo) and '文禄二中山与左衛門' (Second year of the Buroku era, Yozaemon NAKAYAMA) hallmarked and were said to be ordered by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI at the Bunroku War.
Hakatagokuyo Chogin: Chogin with '御公用' (Gokuyo) and '文禄二中山与左衛門' (Second year of the Buroku era, Yozaemon NAKAYAMA) hallmarked and were said to be ordered by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI at the Bunroku War.

sen.j: 天又一丁銀（てんまたいちちょうぎん）：文禄2年（1593年）鋳造で山奉行、天野又衛門および周防国の「一の坂銀山」を指すとされる。
sen.e: Tenmataichi Chogin: These Chogin are thought to be made in 1593 by Yamabugyo (manager of a mountain) Mataemon AMANO and from 'Ichinosaka Silver Mine' in the Suo Province.
Tenmataichi Chogin: These Chogin are thought to be made in 1593 by Yamabugyo (manager of a mountain) Mataemon AMANO and from 'Ichinosaka Silver Mine' in the Suo Province.
Tenmataichi Chogin: These Chogin are thought to be made in 1593 by Yamabugyo (manager of a mountain) Mataemon AMANO and from 'Ichinosaka Silver Mine' in the Suo Province.

sen.j: 小銀（しょうぎん）：譲葉丁銀に「小銀」の極印が打たれる。
sen.e: Shogin: These are Yuzuriha Chogin with '小銀' (Shogin) hallmark.
Shogin: These are Yuzuriha Chogin with '小銀' (Shogin) hallmark.
Shogin: These are Yuzuriha Chogin with '小銀' (Shogin) hallmark.

sen.j: 八福丁銀（はちふくちょうぎん）：横書きの「福八」の極印が打たれる。
sen.e: Hachifuku Chogin: These are Chogin with 'Fukuhachi' hallmarked horizontally.
Hachifuku Chogin: These are Chogin with 'Fukuhachi' hallmarked horizontally.
Hachifuku Chogin: These are Chogin with 'Fukuhachi' hallmarked horizontally.

sen.j: 大与大丁銀（だいよだいちょうぎん）：「大与大（花押）」の極印が打たれる。
sen.e: Daiyodai Chogin: These are Chogin with '大与大' (Daiyodai Kao [a written seal mark])'.
Daiyodai Chogin: These are Chogin with '大与大' (Daiyodai Kao [a written seal mark])'.
Daiyodai Chogin: These are Chogin with '大与大' (Daiyodai Kao [a written seal mark])'.

sen.j: 菊一文字印銀（きくいちもんじいんぎん）：慶長3年（1598年）頃に堺の南鐐座職人により慶長丁銀の鋳造にあたり、家康の上覧に供されたもの。
sen.e: Kikuichimonji Ingin: These Chogin were presented to Ieyasu TOKUGAWA by a craftsman of Nanryoza, Sakai City in 1598 when Ieyasu was planning to produce Keicho Chogin coins.
Kikuichimonji Ingin: These Chogin were presented to Ieyasu TOKUGAWA by a craftsman of Nanryoza, Sakai City in 1598 when Ieyasu was planning to produce Keicho Chogin coins.
Kikuichimonji Ingin: These Chogin were presented to Ieyasu TOKUGAWA by a craftsman of Nanryoza, Sakai City in 1598 when Ieyasu was planning to produce Keicho Chogin coins.

sen.j: 夷一文字印銀（えびすいちもんじいんぎん）：南鐐座職人により慶長丁銀の鋳造にあたり、家康の上覧に供されたもの。
sen.e: Ebisuichimonji Ingin: These are sample Chogin and were presented to Ieyasu by a craftsman of Nanryoza, Sakai City when Ieyasu was planning to produce Keicho Chogin coins.
Ebisuichimonji Ingin: These are sample Chogin and were presented to Ieyasu by a craftsman of Nanryoza, Sakai City when Ieyasu was planning to produce Keicho Chogin coins.
Ebisuichimonji Ingin: These are sample Chogin and were presented to Ieyasu by a craftsman of Nanryoza, Sakai City when Ieyasu was planning to produce Keicho Chogin coins.

sen.j: 括袴丁銀（くくりはかまちょうぎん）：南鐐座の湯浅作兵衛が慶長丁銀の鋳造にあたり、家康の上覧に供され選定されたもので、大黒天の袴の裾が括られている。
sen.e: Kukurihakama Chogin: These Chogin, with an image of Daikokuten (Great Black God) with the hems of his Hakama pants bound, were made by Sakube YUASA of Nanryoza and presented to Ieyasu TOKUGAWA when Ieyasu was planning to produce Keicho Chogin coins and this was the one that was selected.

Kukurihakama Chogin: These Chogin, with an image of Daikokuten (Great Black God) with the hems of his Hakama pants bound, were made by Sakube YUASA of Nanryoza and presented to Ieyasu TOKUGAWA when Ieyasu was planning to produce Keicho Chogin coins and this was the one that was selected.

Kukurihakama Chogin: These Chogin, with an image of Daikokuten (Great Black God) with the hems of his Hakama pants bound, were made by Sakube YUASA of Nanryoza and presented to Ieyasu TOKUGAWA when Ieyasu was planning to produce Keicho Chogin coins and this was the one that was selected.

sen.j: 澤瀉丁銀（おもだかちょうぎん）：湯浅作兵衛が慶長丁銀の発行に先立って試鋳したものと推定され、「常是」、「寳」および「大黒像」に加えて家紋の一覧沢瀉（おもだか）の極印が打たれる。
sen.e: Omodaka Chogin: These Chogin were thought to be sample made by Sakube YUASA before the circulation of Keicho Chogin and had hallmarks with characters for '常是' (Joze [Sakube's heredity name]) and '寳' (Ho [valuable]) and an 'image of Daikoku' as well as the Kamon (family crest) of Omodaka.

Omodaka Chogin: These Chogin were thought to be sample made by Sakube YUASA before the circulation of Keicho Chogin and had hallmarks with characters for '常是' (Joze [Sakube's heredity name]) and '寳' (Ho [valuable]) and an 'image of Daikoku' as well as the Kamon (family crest) of Omodaka.

Omodaka Chogin: These Chogin were thought to be sample made by Sakube YUASA before the circulation of Keicho Chogin and had hallmarks with characters for '常是' (Joze [Sakube's heredity name]) and '寳' (Ho [valuable]) and an 'image of Daikoku' as well as the Kamon (family crest) of Omodaka.
